questions.text: A male patient presents with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections (URTI). Laboratory evaluation reveals low immunoglobulin levels, with IgG antibodies absent. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bruton's agammaglobulinemia

 

The presentation strongly suggests Bruton's agammaglobulinemia, characterized by:

 

  • Male patient (X-linked condition)
  • Recurrent upper respiratory infections
  • Absence of IgG antibodies (agammaglobulinemia)
  • B-cell deficiency due to BTK gene mutation

 

This condition can be remembered by the "B's":

 

  • Boys (male patients)
  • B-cells affected
  • BTK gene mutation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID): Affects both T and B cells, presents earlier in life with more severe manifestations including opportunistic infections.

 

Option C. Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID): Usually presents later in life and affects both males and females. Has variable immunoglobulin levels rather than complete absence.

 

Option D. Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy: Temporary condition that resolves by age 2, with less severe manifestations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bruton's agammaglobulinemia as an X-linked condition characterized by absent B cells, agammaglobulinemia, and recurrent infections in male patients.

choices.text: Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days
Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days
Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding fetal circulation is incorrect ? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days

 

The foramen ovale is an opening in the interatrial septum that allows blood to flow directly from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the lungs. After birth, as the baby begins to breathe and the lungs expand, the pressure in the left atrium increases relative to the right atrium, causing the flap-like valve of the foramen ovale to close.

 

Functional closure, where the valve is pressed shut due to the pressure difference between the atria, usually occurs immediately after birth. Anatomical closure, where the tissue actually grows together and seals the foramen, typically occurs within the first year of life, but not as quickly as 3 to 5 days. Hence, this statement is false.

 

Usually it takes anywhere between 1 to 12 months for the anatomical closure of foramen ovale

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days:

 

  • The ductus venosus connects the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava, allowing oxygenated blood from the placenta to bypass the liver and flow directly to the heart.
  • After birth, the ductus venosus constricts and eventually closes, typically within a few days to a week. It becomes a fibrous cord known as the ligamentum venosum.

 

Option C. Right umbilical vein is absent:

 

  • In fetal circulation, there are two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein. The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus. It's noteworthy that only the left umbilical vein persists, while the right one regresses early in development. Hence, this statement is accurate.

 

Option D. Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks:

 

  • The ductus arteriosus is a vessel that connects the pulmonary artery to the descending aorta. It allows blood to bypass the fetal lungs, which are not yet functional for breathing.
  • After birth, increased oxygen concentration and decreased levels of certain prostaglandins cause the ductus arteriosus to constrict. Functional closure usually happens within the first couple of days after birth, and it undergoes anatomical closure (becoming the ligamentum arteriosum) typically within the first few weeks to months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anatomical closure of the foramen ovale takes 1 month to a year.

questions.text: What type of joint is demonstrated in the highlighted region of the vertebral articulation shown? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synovial

 

The joint marked in the above image is a synovial joint called the costotransverse and costovertebral joint.

 

These are the most common type of joints in the body. The articulating ends of the bones in these joints are covered with articular cartilage. These bones are enclosed within an articular capsule which has an outer fibrous layer (giving it strength) and an inner synovial membrane which secretes synovial fluid (providing lubrication and nutrients to the joint). Examples include the knee joint, elbow joint, and many others.

 

They are diarthrotic, meaning they are freely movable. The exact range of movement and type of movement (e.g., hinge, pivot, ball-and-socket) varies depending on the specific joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: This is a type of fibrous joint where the bones are joined by a ligament or a membrane. The most commonly referred syndesmosis is the one between the tibia and fibula in the leg, held together by the interosseous membrane and the anterior and posterior tibiofibular ligaments.

 

  • It allows for a slight movement (making it amphiarthrotic), particularly when the foot is dorsiflexed or plantarflexed.

 

Option B. Synarthrosis: This term describes a joint that allows very minimal or no movement. It encompasses several types of joints including sutures (between skull bones), gomphoses (between a tooth and its socket), and synchondroses (which we'll discuss next).

 

  • These are largely immovable joints. They serve to provide stability in certain areas of the body, like the skull, where movement is not desired.

 

Option C. Synchondrosis: This is a subtype of synarthrosis, and it's a type of cartilaginous joint where bones are joined together by hyaline cartilage. A classic example is the joint between the first rib and the sternum, or the epiphyseal plates in growing bones.

 

  • They are immovable (synarthrotic). The primary purpose of these joints is to allow growth of the bone while providing stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Description of the joint present in the thoracic region are as follows:

choices.text: A case of superfetation
One infant is atavistic
A case of superfecundation
One infant is suppositious

questions.text: A married woman gives birth to twins. The husband doubts he is the father and gets a paternity test done. The test shows that he is the father of one infant but not the other. This is? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A case of superfecundation

 

Explanation:

 

Superfecundation:

 

  • This refers to the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different acts of intercourse, potentially involving different partners.
  • This scenario explains how twins can have different fathers, as one ovum could be fertilized by sperm from the husband, and the other by sperm from another man.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfetation: This refers to fertilization of two ova from different menstrual cycles. It is an extremely rare phenomenon and has never been documented in humans, though it is known to occur in some animals.

 

Option B. One infant is atavistic: Atavism refers to the appearance of characteristics found in distant ancestors but not observed in recent generations. It does not apply to paternity.

 

Option D. One infant is suppositious: Suppositious refers to something that is fraudulently substituted. This term does not explain the situation of having different fathers for twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation is the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different partners, explaining how twins can have different fathers.

 

Ref: Page no 2188, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus. What is his GCS score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E2V3M4

 

The GCS score of this patient is E2V3M4

 

  • Opening eves to a painful stimulus - E2
  • Speak inappropriately - V3
  • Withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus - M4

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is an essential tool for assessing the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury.
  • It involves evaluating the eye opening response, verbal response, and motor response, with scores ranging from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully awake).
  •  Understanding how to correctly assess and calculate the GCS score is crucial for determining the severity of the injury and guiding appropriate medical intervention.

choices.text: Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter
Defective peristalsis
Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus
Decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the pathology of achalasia cardia? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus 

 

Achalasia cardia is characterized by decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

 

The LES relaxes during swallowing due to the release of nitric oxide and vasoactive intestinal polypeptide from inhibitory neurons, as well as the interruption of normal cholinergic signaling. These inhibitory neurons degenerate in achalasia cardia, resulting in decreased NO and VIP release. This results in increased LES tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter: This is incorrect. In achalasia cardia, there is incomplete relaxation of the LES, not relaxation.

 

Option B. Defective peristalsis: While this statement is related to achalasia cardia, it is not the most accurate or complete description of the pathology. The correct answer focuses specifically on the decreased release of NO and VIP, which directly explains the increased LES tone and subsequent symptoms.

 

Option D. Decreased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter: This is incorrect. In achalasia cardia, the tone of the LES is increased, not decreased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of achalasia cardia is as follows:

 

  1. Incomplete relaxation of LES
  2. Increased tone of LES
  3. Absent peristalsis (aperistalsis)

questions.text: As per WHO, the definition of blindness is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) <3/60.

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) defines blindness as having visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction. This means that a person who is blind cannot see at 3 meters what someone with normal vision can see at 60 meters. This definition is used globally to classify and diagnose blindness.

 

The same definition is used in the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) in India, ensuring consistency in how blindness is categorized both internationally and within the country.

 

Note –

 

  • In India, the current prevalence of blindness is 0.36%.
  • The most common cause of blindness is cataract (62%) >> refractive error (19.7%). 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blindness, as defined by the WHO, is visual acuity of less than 3/60 in the better eye with the best possible correction.

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive device shown in the photograph: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lippes Loop

 

The contraceptive device shown in the photograph is the Lippes Loop, which is an inert, non-medicated intrauterine device (IUD). The Lippes Loop is categorized as a first-generation IUD and is one of the earliest forms of intrauterine contraception. Unlike modern IUDs, which often contain copper or hormones, the Lippes Loop does not contain any active substances.

 

It is made of plastic and has a distinctive S-shape, which was designed to fit within the uterus. However, due to its high failure rate compared to newer, medicated IUDs, it is not commonly used today. Modern IUDs are typically either copper-based (second-generation) or hormone-releasing (third-generation), which offer better efficacy and safety profiles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper T 380 A: This is a second-generation IUD that contains copper. It is more effective than the Lippes Loop due to its medicated nature, which creates an inflammatory reaction toxic to sperm and eggs, preventing pregnancy.

 

 

Options B. Mirena and D. Levonorgestrel IUD (LNG-IUD): Mirena is a third-generation, hormone-releasing IUD that contains levonorgestrel, measuring 32 × 32 mm placed for up to 5 years

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lippes Loop is an older, non-medicated, inert IUD that was once widely used but has been largely replaced by more effective copper and hormone-releasing IUDs in modern contraceptive practice.

questions.text: A 58-year-old hypertensive patient with a history of myocardial infarction (MI) presents with an acute attack of migraine. Which of the following medications should not be given for migraine in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sumatriptan

 

Sumatriptan belongs to a class of drugs called triptans, which are commonly used to treat migraines. Triptans work by constricting blood vessels in the brain, which helps to relieve migraine pain. However, they can also cause vasoconstriction in other parts of the body, including the coronary arteries. This vasoconstriction can potentially trigger coronary artery spasm, reducing blood flow to the heart and worsening the condition of a patient with a history of myocardial infarction (MI).

 

Sumatriptan and ergotamine are commonly used in treating migraine attacks by stimulating 5HT1B1D receptors, which induce vasoconstriction in the brain to alleviate migraine symptoms. While this vasoconstriction is beneficial within the brain, it can have harmful effects elsewhere. Both drugs can cause vasoconstriction in peripheral blood vessels and the coronary artery, potentially leading to serious conditions:

 

  • Peripheral Vasoconstriction: Could result in gangrene, with ergotamine having a higher risk than sumatriptan.
  • Coronary Artery Spasm: This can exacerbate conditions like myocardial infarction (MI).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ibuprofen: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can be used to manage mild to moderate migraine pain. It does not cause vasoconstriction and is generally safe for patients with a history of MI.

 

Option C. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used for migraine prophylaxis (prevention). It does not cause vasoconstriction and can even be beneficial in patients with hypertension, which is a risk factor for both migraine and MI.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that can also be used for migraine prophylaxis. It has vasodilatory effects and does not pose a risk of coronary artery spasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triptans, such as sumatriptan & ergotamine, are contraindicated in patients with a history of myocardial infarction or other significant cardiovascular diseases due to their potential to cause coronary artery vasoconstriction

questions.text: Identify the correct labelling of the ulcer in the given image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Edge

 

Parts of an ulcer are clearly defined:

 

 

Edge: Junction between floor and skin 

 

Floor: Visible surface of ulcer that can be seen

 

Base: Tissue on which floor rests (not visible but can be palpated)

 

Margin: Where edge merges with surrounding healthy skin

 

Key characteristics:

 

Edge provides important diagnostic clues:

 

  • Punched out in trophic ulcer
  • Undermined in tuberculous ulcer
  • Everted in malignant ulcer
  • Sloping in healing ulcer

 

Educational Objective:

 

Edge of an ulcer is the junction between floor and surrounding skin, and its characteristics provide important diagnostic clues.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is dependent on Vitamin C for its activity? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prolyl hydroxylase

 

Prolyl hydroxylase is a key enzyme in collagen synthesis that requires vitamin C (ascorbic acid) as a cofactor. This enzyme catalyzes the hydroxylation of proline residues to form hydroxyproline in collagen. The process is essential for:

 

  • Post-translational modification of collagen
  • Formation of stable collagen triple helix
  • Proper collagen cross-linking
  • Maintaining collagen strength and stability

 

In vitamin C deficiency, proline cannot be hydroxylated to hydroxyproline, leading to unstable collagen and symptoms of scurvy like:

 

  • Poor wound healing
  • Bleeding gums
  • Easy bruising

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect because this enzyme does not exist in collagen synthesis pathway. The actual enzyme involved in lysine modification is lysyl hydroxylase, which also requires vitamin C.

 

Option B. Lysyl oxidase: Incorrect because this enzyme requires copper as a cofactor, not vitamin C. It forms cross-links in collagen by oxidizing lysine and hydroxylysine residues.

 

Option C. Hydroxypropyl kinase: Incorrect because this is a non-existent enzyme name. No such enzyme is involved in collagen synthesis or vitamin C-dependent reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin C is an essential cofactor for prolyl hydroxylase, which is crucial for collagen synthesis and stability. Deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in scurvy.

choices.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done
Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation

 

An electrocardiogram (ECG) is crucial in the initial evaluation of a patient presenting with syncope, particularly to rule out cardiac causes such as atrial fibrillation, which can lead to episodic reductions in cardiac output and cerebral perfusion. Atrial fibrillation, a common arrhythmia in the elderly, can cause transient episodes of dizziness and loss of consciousness due to irregular and often rapid heart rate leading to ineffective heart pumping.

 

Note - In an elderly w/ first episode of syncope detailed history, clinical exam (cardiac, postural BP, neuro exam), basic investigations (ECG, +/- ECHO) is required

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done: While a CT scan might be considered if there is suspicion of a neurological cause after a thorough clinical evaluation, it is not automatically the next step following a normal ECG, especially in the absence of neurological symptoms or signs suggestive of structural brain disease.

 

Option C. Tilt-table testing: This is generally reserved for cases where recurrent unexplained episodes of syncope occur, particularly when a vasovagal or orthostatic cause is suspected, not typically used after a first episode unless specific indications are present.

 

Option D. Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms: Vestibular neuritis can cause severe vertigo and imbalance but typically does not cause loss of consciousness, making it less likely in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients presenting with an acute onset of dizziness and syncope, an ECG is an essential first step to rule out arrhythmic causes such as atrial fibrillation. Additional diagnostic steps should be guided by the findings of the initial evaluation and specific clinical indicators.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Atrial fibrillation/Chap 251

questions.text: An infant is brought to OPD with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia. Neuroimaging with CT reveals periventricular calcifications. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital cytomegalovirus infection

 

Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection. The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic. Congenital infection can affect all organ systems. Periventricular calcification is characteristic. The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital rubella syndrome: Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection. If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances. More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections. Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles). Triad – congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

Option B. Congenital herpes simplex virus infection: The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option C. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Periventricular calcifications on neuroimaging, along with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia, are characteristic of congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. Upon examination, it is found that the patient is unable to pass urine and there is visible blood at the meatus. A retrograde urethrogram was performed as shown below. What is the most likely site of urethral injury? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Membranous urethra

 

  • Given the presentation of the patient - specifically the inability to pass urine, visible blood at the meatus after a motor vehicle accident and the RGU appearance - the membranous urethra is the most likely site of injury.
  • This is because it's closely associated with pelvic fractures, which are common in such accidents.
  • The management includes a retrograde urethrogram to confirm the injury, followed by the insertion of a suprapubic catheter to bypass the injured segment and allow for healing.
  • Membranous urethral rupture is typically associated with pelvic fractures and presents with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and a high-riding prostate on digital examination.
  • Bruising may also be visible over the pubic area, scrotum, and penis. Urine extravasates in the perivesical space.
  • The membranous urethra is the shortest and narrowest part of the male urethra and passes through the urogenital diaphragm.
  • This segment is particularly vulnerable in cases of pelvic fractures, often seen in motor vehicle accidents.
  • Clinical features, such as blood at the meatus and urinary retention as seen in the case, often point to an injury in this region.
  • On rectal examination, a high-riding prostate may be palpated, indicating disruption of the urethra below the prostate. This choice aligns with the given scenario and is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulbar Urethra: It's a common site of injury due to straddle injuries (like falling onto a bicycle crossbar) because of its exposed location. It would typically result in a perineal hematoma.

 

Option B. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: This occurs due to a blow to the pelvis; however, no blood is seen at the urethral meatus.

 

Option D. Penile Urethra: This portion is within the shaft of the penis, encased within the corpus spongiosum. Trauma to the penile urethra usually results from direct trauma to the penis, such as in the context of a penile fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Membranous urethral injuries are common in pelvic fractures, presenting with urinary retention, blood at the meatus, and possibly a high-riding prostate on rectal examination. Retrograde urethrogram is used for confirmation.

questions.text: An acute encephalitis outbreak has occurred within the community, prompting the initiation of a vaccination campaign. Which of the following is true about the vaccine given in this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Killed and intramuscular

 

Explanation:

 

The question is referring to Japanese Encephalitis (JE) outbreaks, which are not uncommon in India and parts of Southeast Asia. During such outbreaks, emergency vaccination campaigns are often undertaken to control the spread of disease.

 

The most commonly used vaccine in these public health campaigns in India earlier used to be Live JE SA 14-14-2 vaccine (subcutaneous). But nowadays, the inactivated (killed) Vero cell–derived JE vaccine - JENVAC is used intramuscularly.

 

Hence, the correct response based on updated national guidelines is:

 

Killed and intramuscular.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Live and subcutaneous:

While the SA 14-14-2 vaccine is a live, attenuated vaccine given subcutaneously, recent protocols for outbreak settings increasingly prefer killed vaccines like JENVAC, especially in adult populations and for mass campaigns due to ease of storage and safety. Live vaccine SA -14-14-2 is quite good during outbreaks too. But JENVAC has an edge over SA 14-14-2 because of the higher immunity levels it creates with a single dose. Hence, although previously correct, SA 14-14-2 is no longer the preferred or updated answer.

 

Option C) Live and intramuscular:

Live vaccines (like SA 14-14-2) are given subcutaneously. IM route is not used for Live JE SA 14-14-2 routinely.

 

Option D) Killed and subcutaneous:

Killed JE vaccines (like JENVAC or IXIARO) are administered intramuscularly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of a Japanese Encephalitis outbreak, the vaccine currently recommended and used in mass immunization campaigns in India is a killed (inactivated) vaccine administered via the intramuscular route, such as JENVAC. While older guidelines or some regions may have used the live attenuated SA 14-14-2 vaccine given subcutaneously, updated practices now favor the inactivated IM vaccine due to its broader safety profile and compatibility with adult vaccination. Always refer to the most recent national immunization guidelines when answering such public health–related MCQs.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV-positive patient died, and his body was brought for post-mortem. The method of autopsy to be done is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Rokitansky technique

 

Rokitansky Method-

 

  • In situ
  • Organs dissected inside the body
  • for highly infectious disease, e.g., HIV to prevent the spread of infection

 

 

 

Rokitansky Method

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ghon’s method (en block):

 

Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks

 

 

Ghon’s Method

 

Option B. Letulle’s method (En masse)

 

  • Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
  • Best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other                         
  • Disadvantage: difficult to handle large mass.

 

       

Letulle’s Method

 

Option C. Virchow’s method

 

  • Each and every organ is removed one by one (e.g., each lung, each kidney, heart separately)
  • Relations of organs are not preserved
  • Most commonly used technique (easier to perform)

 

 

Virchow’s Method

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rokitansky technique involves dissecting organs in situ and is the preferred method for highly infectious diseases like HIV to prevent the spread of infection.

questions.text: Location of Bartholin cyst at the vaginal orifice is at? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior 1/3rd

 

Bartholin glands are located at the posterior part of the vaginal introitus. These glands are responsible for secreting mucus to provide lubrication for the vagina. A Bartholin cyst occurs when the duct of the Bartholin gland becomes blocked, leading to the accumulation of fluid.

 

  • Location: The Bartholin glands are situated at the lower part of the vaginal opening, specifically at the junction between the posterior one-third and the anterior two-thirds of the labia minora. Thus, when a Bartholin cyst forms, it typically presents at this posterior one-third region of the vaginal orifice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Bartholin cyst is located at the posterior one-third of the vaginal orifice, at the margin of the labia minora and the vaginal introitus.

questions.text: A student got his jaw locked while yawning. Identify the muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lateral pterygoid

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint is the lateral pterygoid.

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle has two heads: superior (or upper) and inferior (or lower). The superior head attaches to the articular disc and the capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). This muscle plays a crucial role in the opening of the mouth, protrusion of the mandible, and moving the jaw from side to side. Dysfunction or spasms of this muscle could contribute to jaw locking during yawning. The lateral pterygoid is, therefore, closely associated with the movements and function of the TMJ.

 

All Innervated by CN V3

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temporalis: The temporalis muscle originates from the temporal fossa and inserts onto the coronoid process of the mandible. It's primarily responsible for closing the mouth and is involved in elevating and retracting the mandible. It does not attach to the articular disc of the TMJ, but it plays a role in jaw movement.

 

Option C. Medial pterygoid: The medial pterygoid muscle is similar in function to the masseter muscle and helps in elevating the mandible, thus assisting in closing the mouth. It also plays a role in moving the jaw from side to side. However, like the temporalis, it doesn't directly attach to the articular disc of the TMJ.

 

Option D. Masseter: The masseter muscle is one of the primary muscles of mastication (chewing). It originates from the zygomatic arch and inserts onto the lateral aspect of the mandibular angle and ramus. Its primary function is to elevate the mandible, assisting in closing the mouth. It does not have an attachment to the articular disc of the TMJ but is important for jaw function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle, particularly its superior head, is uniquely attached to the TMJ's articular disc and plays a pivotal role in jaw movements including mouth opening and lateral movements, making it relevant in cases of jaw locking.

choices.text: Use MR vaccine and discard pentavalent vaccine
Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

questions.text: An auxiliary nurse midwife is tasked with organizing a vaccination camp within a rural community. She has been provided with 2 vials that have been unsealed. Among these, one contains a pentavalent vaccine, while the other holds an MR vaccine. What options does she have in terms of effectively using these vials? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Use pentavalent vaccine and discard MR vaccine

 

According to the Open Vial Policy, certain vaccines can be used for subsequent sessions for up to 4 weeks after opening, provided they have been stored properly and are not expired. This policy helps to minimize vaccine wastage and ensure efficient use of available vaccines.

 

Open Vial Policy (2015)

 

  • Opened vaccine vials can be used in subsequent session ‘UPTO 4 WEEKS’
  • Open vial policy – 
    • Applicable for - Hep B, OPV, DPT, Liquid pentavalent, TT, PCV, IPV, HiB
    • Not applicable for - BCG, MR, JE, RVV, Covid-19 vaccines
  • Expiry date should not pass, VVM within usability limits, Cold chain maintenance
  • Vaccine vial septum not submerged in water or contaminated, Aseptic technique used to withdraw doses
  • Record date and time of each vial opening
  • At end of session return all open vials to Cold chain:
    • Reusable open vials: DPT, DT, Hepatitis B, Pentavalent
    • Non-reusable open vials: Measles, BCG, JE (Destroy after 48 hours or Next session whichever earlier)
    • If any AEFI reported: Store all vials in Cold chain till completion of investigation

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Under the Open Vial Policy, the auxiliary nurse midwife can use the pentavalent vaccine for subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks after opening, but must discard the MR vaccine as it does not fall under the Open Vial Policy.

questions.text: Which one of the provided thermometers is employed for measuring low air velocity as opposed to the cooling potency of the air? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Kata thermometer 

 

Kata thermometer is used to measure low air velocity rather than the cooling power of the air. It works by measuring the temperature difference between two thin wires heated to different temperatures in a moving air stream. The faster the air moves, the greater the temperature difference between the two wires, allowing the Kata thermometer to measure air velocity.

 

Other Options

Option B. Globe Thermometer: Measures mean radiant temperature, which is the average temperature of all the surfaces surrounding a particular point. This is useful in assessing thermal comfort in environments.

 

Option C. Wet Globe Thermometer: Used to measure heat stress by taking into account temperature, humidity, wind speed, and solar radiation. It is commonly used in the Wet Bulb Globe Temperature (WBGT) index.

Option D. Dial Thermometer: Measures air temperature using a dial indicator. It is a general-purpose thermometer and not specifically designed for measuring air velocity.


Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having nocturnal cough for last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The presence of eosinophilia in an immunosuppressed patient with respiratory symptoms and BAL revealing rhabditiform larvae is suggestive of disseminated strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Strongyloidiasis:

 

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous. The transmission of infection occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine. The larvae moult twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

 

The life cycle of strongyloides is shown below.

 

 

It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms.

 

The term larva currens (meaning 'racing larvae') has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in immunodeficient individuals.

 

Larva currens is shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae of nonhuman species of nematodes that infect via the oral route.

 

Etiological agents causing visceral larva migrans:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Human nematode: Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Zoophilic nematode: Toxocara canis, toxocara cati, Angiostrongylus cantoniensis, Angiostrongylus costaricensis, Anisakis.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Non human nematode: Filarial species, Brugia pahangi, Brugia pate

 

Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
  • ﻿﻿Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
  • ﻿﻿Stool culture and serological tests are also done

 

Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma canium presents with creeping eruption. Cutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

Option B. Capillaria phillipinesis can also cause auto-infection. It commonly presents with severe diarrhea.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection presents as itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus)

 

Educational Objective

 

In patients presenting with respiratory symptoms and eosinophilia, especially those who are immunocompromised, strongyloidiasis should be considered. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent the severe outcomes associated with hyperinfection. Treatment typically involves antiparasitic medications such as ivermectin.

 

Autoinfection: - CHEST (Mnemonic)

 

  1. Cryptosporidium parvum
  2. H. nana larva
  3. Enterobius vermicularis
  4. Strongyloides
  5. Taenia solium

questions.text: A patient is found to have a solitary thyroid nodule. What is the first step in his management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Thyroid profile/TSH

 

The initial evaluation of a solitary thyroid nodule begins with a thyroid profile, specifically measuring thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. This is the first step because the TSH test helps determine whether the nodule is functioning (producing thyroid hormone) or non-functioning. If TSH is suppressed, indicating a hyperfunctioning (autonomous) nodule, further evaluation with a radionuclide scan may be appropriate to assess whether the nodule is "hot" (functioning). If TSH is normal or elevated, the next steps typically include an ultrasound (USG) of the neck and possibly fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy, depending on ultrasound findings. The management plan is tailored based on these initial results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radioiodine with I123: This diagnostic scan is typically used after initial thyroid function tests suggest a hyperfunctioning nodule. It is not the first step.

 

Option C. Radioiodine with I131: I131 is primarily used for therapeutic purposes, such as treating hyperthyroidism or certain types of thyroid cancer, not for initial diagnostic evaluation of a thyroid nodule.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography): CECT is not routinely used as the first step in the evaluation of thyroid nodules due to its limited ability to characterize thyroid nodules compared to ultrasound and potential interference with subsequent radioactive iodine therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of a solitary thyroid nodule is to assess thyroid function with a TSH test. This guides further diagnostic and management strategies based on whether the nodule is functioning or not.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with gum bleeding and fever for the past 2 months. General examination showed pallor and the systemic examination was unremarkable. Laboratory examination revealed Hb level- 3 gm/dI, TLC-1500/microL, platelet count - 15000/microL. Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and the reticulocyte count is 0.5. Bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes but no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis? (Hb- Hemoglobin, TLC- Total leucocyte count)? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia

 

The given clinical scenario showing a young male with gum bleeding, fever, pancytopenia, and a low reticulocyte count with bone marrow showing fatty streaks and no immature cells is suggestive of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

 

Key Diagnostic Features of Aplastic Anemia:

 

  • Pancytopenia (low Hb, WBC, and platelets)
  • Hypocellular (fatty) bone marrow
  • No immature/blast cells
  • Low reticulocyte count (indicates bone marrow failure)
  • Macrocytes due to ineffective hematopoiesis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH is characterized by hemolysis, hemoglobinuria (especially in the morning), and thrombosis. The presentation of pancytopenia with bone marrow aplasia is more suggestive of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

 

Option C. Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS): MDS are a diverse group of hematopoietic clonal stem cell disorders characterized by abnormal development of various marrow elements (i.e., dysmyelopoiesis), cytopenias, cellular marrow, and ineffective blood cell formation.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis can cause pancytopenia if the bone marrow is involved, but the bone marrow would show granulomas rather than the fatty streaks and absence of immature cells seen in aplastic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pancytopenia

 

I. Aplastic anemia

 

II. Pancytopenia with normal or increased marrow cellularity

 

e.g.

 

  1.  Myelodysplastic syndromes
  2. Hypersplenism
  3.  Megaloblastic anemia

 

III. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

 

IV. Bone marrow infiltrations

 

e.g:

 

  1. Hematologic malignancies (leukemias, lymphomas, myeloma)
  2. Non-hematologic metastatic malignancies
  3. Storage diseases
  4. Osteopetrosis
  5. Myelofibrosis

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident was brought to the emergency by the family members. His CT scan was done which showed the following image. Which of the following can be given to this patient in this situation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin K

 

The CT scan image shows a subdural hematoma (SDH), which is a type of intracranial hemorrhage characterized by a crescent-shaped bleed along the brain's surface, often resulting from head trauma. In the case of traumatic intracranial hemorrhage, the primary concern is to stop the bleeding and manage intracranial pressure.

 

Vitamin K is an essential factor in the clotting cascade and is used to promote clotting and reduce bleeding. It is especially useful if the patient is suspected to be on anticoagulant therapy, as it helps counteract the effects of such medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteplase: Alteplase is a thrombolytic agent used to dissolve clots in ischemic stroke or myocardial infarction. Administering it in the context of a hemorrhagic stroke would worsen the bleeding.

 

Option B. Retiplase: Similar to alteplase, retiplase is another thrombolytic agent and is contraindicated in cases of hemorrhage due to its potential to exacerbate bleeding.

 

Option D. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that prevents clot formation. Giving heparin in a situation of intracranial hemorrhage would further inhibit clotting and worsen the bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of a traumatic intracranial hemorrhage, such as a subdural hematoma, Vitamin K is administered to promote blood clotting and reduce further bleeding, especially if the patient is on anticoagulant therapy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with substernal chest discomfort. On examination, he was hypotensive, drowsy, and had unequal pulses. Which of the following investigations would be the best in this situation to ascertain the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trans-esophageal echocardiography

 

The presentation of acute chest pain, hypotension, drowsiness, and unequal pulses strongly suggests aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate diagnosis and management.

 

Trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is highly sensitive and specific for diagnosing aortic dissection. It can be performed at the bedside, making it ideal for unstable patients. TEE provides detailed images of the aorta and can quickly confirm the presence of an intimal flap, a characteristic finding in aortic dissection.

 

If the patient has been stable, then preferred investigation of choice is CT angiography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CXR PA view: A chest X-ray (CXR) might show a widened mediastinum, which can be a clue to aortic dissection, but it is not definitive. It lacks the sensitivity and specificity needed for a rapid and accurate diagnosis in an emergency setting.

 

Option C. MRI: While MRI can provide excellent detail, it is not suitable for acutely unstable patients due to the time required for the scan and the need to transport the patient to the MRI suite. It is not practical in an emergency setting.

 

Option D. Troponin assay: Troponin assays are used to diagnose myocardial infarction, not aortic dissection. Although troponins can be elevated in some cases of aortic dissection, they do not provide definitive diagnostic information about the dissection itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of suspected aortic dissection, especially in an unstable patient, trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the best diagnostic tool due to its high sensitivity and ability to be performed at the bedside, providing rapid and accurate confirmation of the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following steps is not included in WHO's STEP approach?[NEET  PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Therapeutic assessment

 

  • STEPwise approach to surveillance (STEPS) is a simple, standardized method by WHO for surveillance. It is of two types:
    • STEPwise approach to chronic disease risk factor surveillance
    • STEPwise approach to Stroke surveillance

choices.text: Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex, and tell the mother.
Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex but don’t tell the mother.
Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, don’t check the sex.
Don’t do ultrasound, do ANC only.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G5L4 with all 4-girl children presents at 18 weeks and asks for the sex of the child on ultrasound. This is her first antenatal visit. What should be done? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, don’t check the sex.


The Ans. is C because, according to the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, sex determination of the fetus is illegal and punishable by law. At 18 weeks, the primary purpose of the ultrasound is to assess gestational age and check for any fetal abnormalities as part of the anomaly scan. Checking or revealing the sex of the fetus is prohibited and carries legal consequences. Therefore, the healthcare provider should perform the ultrasound for the medical purposes it is intended for and avoid even viewing the sex of the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex, and tell the mother: is incorrect because checking the sex and informing the mother is illegal under the PCPNDT Act, and can lead to legal repercussions, including imprisonment.

 

Option B. Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex but don’t tell the mother: is also incorrect. Even looking at the fetus’s sex, regardless of whether it is disclosed, is a violation of the law and is punishable.

 

Option D. Don’t do ultrasound, do ANC only: is incorrect because the ultrasound at 18 weeks is necessary for evaluating gestational age and detecting any fetal abnormalities, which are critical aspects of prenatal care.

 

Educational Objective:


The key point to remember is that checking or revealing the sex of the fetus during an ultrasound is illegal under the PCPNDT Act. The ultrasound should only be used for assessing fetal gestational age and abnormalities.

questions.text: Benzathine penicillin is given for the treatment of rheumatic fever. This is which level of prevention? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Secondary level

 

Secondary prevention involves the early detection and treatment of a disease to prevent its progression.

 

In the context of rheumatic fever, if a child has already developed the condition, benzyl benzathine penicillin (BBP) is administered to prevent further complications, such as rheumatic heart disease. This treatment is given in regular doses (1.2 million units in adults or 0.6 million units in children; every 3 weeks) over a period of 5 years or until the child is 18 years old, whichever comes later. This approach is aimed at treating the condition and preventing its worsening, which characterizes secondary prevention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primordial level: This level focuses on preventing the emergence of risk factors in a population. It is not relevant to the treatment of an existing condition like rheumatic fever.

 

Option B. Primary level: This involves preventing the onset of disease in at-risk individuals. In this context, primary prevention would involve giving penicillin to prevent the initial occurrence of rheumatic fever in a child with a streptococcal sore throat.

 

Dose of BBP - 1.2 million units in adults or 0.6 million units in children; single dose; IM stat.

 

Option D. Tertiary level: Tertiary prevention is aimed at reducing the impact of an ongoing illness that has lasting effects. This would involve rehabilitation and managing chronic complications, which is not the primary aim of benzathine penicillin treatment in rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary prevention involves the treatment of existing conditions, such as rheumatic fever, to prevent further complications.

questions.text: A middle aged male presented with features of neck swelling, exophthalmos, sweating, tachycardia and tremors. Which of the following is the likely associated finding in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti thyroid receptor antibody

 

This patient presents with classic signs of hyperthyroidism, including:

 

  • Neck swelling → Goiter
  • Exophthalmos → Bulging eyes
  • Sweating, tachycardia, tremors → Signs of increased sympathetic activity

 

The given history and the picture of the patient suggest a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism the commonest cause of which is Graves’s disease.

 

The most common antibody subtype, known as thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI), is observed in approximately 90% of patients. TSI binds to the TSH receptor and mimics its actions, stimulating adenyl cyclase and increasing the release of thyroid hormones.

 

  • Anti thyroid stimulating antibody cannot be the answer as such an antibody
  • Since TSI stimulates the gland for the formation of thyroid hormones. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-TPO antibody: Associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Option B. Anti-thyroglobulin antibody: Also associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Option C. Anti-thyroid stimulating antibody: Incorrect terminology for TSI, which is already covered under anti-thyroid receptor antibody.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves' disease is associated with anti-thyroid receptor antibodies (TSI), which stimulate the thyroid gland to produce excess thyroid hormones, leading to hyperthyroidism. The presence of neck swelling, exophthalmos, and other hyperthyroid symptoms strongly suggests this diagnosis.

 

Graves Disease – Key Features:

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 1081

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome presents with symptoms suggestive of a gastrinoma. Which of the following is the most common site of occurrence in MEN 1 syndrome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Duodenum

 

Explanation:

 

In patients with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with MEN 1 and are often found in the first and second parts of the duodenum.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) Overview:

 

  • MEN 1 is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the endocrine glands, leading to the development of multiple endocrine tumors.
  • The main features of MEN 1 include:
    • Parathyroid tumors: These cause hyperparathyroidism, the most common feature of MEN 1.
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs): These tumors can be functional (producing hormones) or non-functional. Functional NETs include gastrinomas, insulinomas (causing hypoglycemia), glucagonomas, and VIPomas.
    • Pituitary tumors: These are usually benign but can secrete various hormones, leading to different clinical manifestations such as prolactinomas, growth hormone-secreting tumors (acromegaly), and ACTH-secreting tumors (Cushing's disease).

 

Gastrinoma and Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome:

 

  • Gastrinomas are associated with increased gastric acid production and can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by severe peptic ulcers and gastrin overproduction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Gastrinomas are less commonly found in the jejunum compared to the duodenum in MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option B. Ileum: The ileum is not a common site for gastrinomas in MEN 1 syndrome. The duodenum is the primary site.

 

Option D. Stomach: While gastrinomas can theoretically occur in the stomach, they are most commonly found in the duodenum in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MEN 1 syndrome, gastrinomas are most commonly located in the duodenum. They are the most frequent functional pancreatic endocrine tumors associated with this genetic disorder.

choices.text: Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body
In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation
The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis

questions.text: A previously healthy child presented with acute-onset dyspnea. A chest X-ray shows unilateral hyperinflation of the lungs. What is true for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body

 

The clinical presentation suggests the presence of a foreign body in the airway, most likely in the bronchi, causing incomplete airway obstruction. This would be evident on auscultation as a focal area of decreased air entry. This condition is more common in children under 4 years old, and food items are the most common foreign bodies. Non-irritating types, such as plastic, glass, or metallic foreign bodies, and irritating types, such as vegetables, peanuts, beans, and seeds, are frequently encountered. The right bronchus is more susceptible to foreign body impaction because it is wider and more in line with the tracheal lumen.

 

Evaluation:

 

  • A plain X-ray chest in posteroanterior and lateral views (expiratory films are useful) is performed to evaluate a foreign body in the airway.
  • The X-ray may show the radio-opaque foreign body's size, shape, and location, lobar or segmental atelectasis in complete airway obstruction, or hyperinflation or obstructive emphysema of the affected area due to the ball valve mechanism.

 

Management:

 

  • The management of foreign body airway depends on the location of the foreign body.
  • A laryngeal foreign body can be treated with the Heimlich maneuver, and if it fails, cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy should be performed.
  • Foreign bodies in the trachea and bronchi can be removed using a rigid bronchoscope after adequate hydration and emptying of the stomach.
  • Appropriate antibiotics are given to prevent secondary infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flexible bronchoscopy used for removal: Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred over flexible bronchoscopy for the removal of foreign bodies in the trachea and bronchi because it allows better visualization and manipulation.

 

Option C. In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation: Incomplete obstruction, not complete obstruction, is associated with the ball valve mechanism, which causes hyperinflation by allowing air to enter but not leave the affected area.

 

Option D. The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis: Laryngotracheobronchitis, or croup, is caused by the parainfluenza virus. It commonly affects children aged 6 months to 3 years and presents with a barking cough, biphasic stridor, and low-grade fever. The chest X-ray shows a narrowing of the subglottic region known as the steeple sign, which is not consistent with the presented case of foreign body aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute-onset dyspnea with unilateral hyperinflation on chest X-ray, a focal area of decreased air entry is suggestive of foreign body aspiration, which is more common in children under 4 years old.

questions.text: Relieving pressure of pop off valve in this device is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30-40 cm H2O 

 

The image shows an Ambu bag, which is used to provide positive pressure ventilation to patients. The pop-off valve, also known as a pressure release valve, is a safety feature that prevents the delivery of excessive pressure to the patient's lungs. This valve is typically set to relieve pressure at 30-40 cm H2O, which is sufficient to ventilate the patient without causing barotrauma, which is damage to the lungs from excessive pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pop-off valve in a manual resuscitator is typically set to relieve pressure at 30-40 cm H2O to ensure safe and effective ventilation without causing lung damage.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents at 8 weeks of pregnancy. During the examination, a specific clinical sign is observed. What is the name of the sign being elicited? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hegar sign

 

The image demonstrates Hegar's sign, which is elicited during bimanual examination in early pregnancy. Due to the softening of the lower uterine segment at the level of the isthmus, the examining fingers can be approximated between the cervix and the uterine body. This softening allows the examiner's hands to almost meet at the isthmus level during bimanual examination, which is characteristic of Hegar's sign.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Palmer sign: This is incorrect. Palmer sign refers to the detection of subtle uterine contractions felt during bimanual examination in early pregnancy, not the softening at isthmus.

 

Option C. Internal ballotment: This is incorrect. Internal ballotment is a second-trimester finding (after 16 weeks) where the fetus can be balloted between the examining fingers during vaginal examination.

 

Option D. External ballotment: This is incorrect. External ballotment is also a second-trimester finding elicited through abdominal examination, not applicable at 8 weeks of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hegar's sign as the softening of the lower uterine segment at the isthmus level during early pregnancy, allowing approximation of examining fingers during bimanual examination, and distinguishing it from other pregnancy signs.

questions.text: The image below depicts which of the following types of cell-to-cells signaling? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Paracrine

 

Explanation

 

The given image shows the paracrine cell-to-cell signaling mechanism where signaling molecules released by a cell only affect nearby target cells.

 

An example of paracrine signaling is the release of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor released by the endothelial cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Autocrine: Incorrect. In autocrine signaling, a cell targets itself, releasing signals that bind to receptors on its own surface.

 

Option C. Endocrine: Incorrect. Endocrine signaling involves hormones that are released into the bloodstream and affect distant target cells.

 

Option D. Merocrine: Incorrect. Merocrine refers to a type of exocrine secretion where cells secrete substances via exocytosis; it is not a type of intercellular signaling but a mode of secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thymus

 

The histological image shows the thymus, a primary lymphoid organ responsible for T-cell maturation. Key features of the thymus seen in the image include:

 

  • Lobular architecture with a cortex (darker staining due to densely packed immature T cells) and a medulla (lighter staining due to less dense mature T cells).
  • Presence of Hassall's corpuscles in the medulla, which are unique to the thymus.
  • Absence of lymphoid follicles, which differentiates it from secondary lymphoid organs like lymph nodes and spleen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymph Node: Incorrect. A lymph node has distinct cortical follicles, germinal centers, and a medullary sinus. The image does not show any of these structures, ruling out the lymph node.

 

Option B. Palatine Tonsil: Incorrect. Palatine tonsils contain lymphoid follicles and crypts. Crypts are absent in the given image, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Spleen: Incorrect. The spleen exhibits red pulp (vascular sinusoidal spaces) and white pulp (lymphoid nodules with central arterioles). These features are absent in the image, excluding the spleen as the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the optimum pressure for VAC? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 100 to 130 mm of Hg

 

Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) therapy, also known as negative pressure wound therapy, is used to promote wound healing by applying controlled negative pressure to the wound area. The optimum pressure for VAC therapy is typically around -125 mm Hg, but a commonly acceptable range is 100 to 130 mm Hg. This pressure range helps to remove exudate, reduce edema, promote granulation tissue formation, and increase local blood flow, thereby enhancing the wound healing process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 70 to 100 mm of Hg: This pressure range is lower than the optimum and may not be as effective in promoting wound healing, as it may not provide sufficient negative pressure to achieve the desired therapeutic effects.

 

Option C. 30 to 50 mm of Hg: This range is far too low to be effective for VAC therapy and would not provide the necessary suction to enhance wound healing.

 

Option D. 10 to 30 mm of Hg: This is significantly below the recommended pressure range and would not contribute effectively to wound management using VAC therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The optimum pressure for Vacuum-Assisted Closure therapy is between 100 to 130 mm Hg, with -125 mm Hg being the most commonly used setting to promote effective wound healing.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with irregular periods, acne, and excessive hair growth (hirsutism). What is the initial treatment of choice? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lifestyle measures

 

In PCOS management, lifestyle modifications are always the first-line approach before initiating any pharmacological treatment. patients should be counseled for lifestyle measures for at least 6 months before starting any medications. This includes focus on improving BMI through diet and exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Metformin: While metformin can be used in PCOS management, particularly for insulin resistance, it is not the first-line treatment. It is considered after lifestyle modifications have been attempted.

 

Option B. Combined OCPs: Though OCPs are effective in managing PCOS symptoms like irregular periods and hyperandrogenism, they are typically started only if lifestyle modifications fail to show improvement after 6 months.

 

Option C. Clomiphene citrate: This is used specifically for ovulation induction in PCOS patients seeking fertility. It is not the first-line treatment for general PCOS management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lifestyle modifications (diet and exercise) are the first-line treatment for PCOS, to be tried for 6 months before considering pharmacological options.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burn Marshall

 

The Burns Marshall maneuver is a technique used during breech deliveries. This maneuver involves gently swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen by holding the baby's ankles. The purpose is to facilitate the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation. It requires careful handling to avoid neck injury and to maintain control during delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wigand: The Wigand maneuver is another technique used in obstetrics, but it is not related to breech delivery or involves swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen.

 

Option C. Mauriceau Smellie Viet: This maneuver is used during breech delivery but involves supporting the baby's body on the obstetrician's forearm with the index and middle fingers placed on the maxilla to flex the head. It does not involve swinging the baby and is distinct from the Burns Marshall maneuver.

 

 

Option D. Prague: The Prague maneuver is used in breech delivery, specifically when the baby's arms are extended above the head. The obstetrician rotates the baby to facilitate arm delivery before the head, differing from the Burns Marshall maneuver.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Burns Marshall maneuver is characterized by gently swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen to assist in the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation.

questions.text: Identify the blue-colored area shown in the image below?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mid-pelvis

 

The true pelvis is divided into 3 planes

 

  1. Plane of Inlet
  2. Plane of Mid cavity (Mid-Pelvis)
  3. Plane of Outlet

 

The Plane of Mid Cavity (Or Mid-Pelvis) is what is shown in the image

 

Pelvic Cavity

 

This has 2 planes

 

  1. Plane of Greatest Dimension: 
    • At the level of S2/3
    • Circular plane; AP diameter = Transverse diameter = 12.5 cm
    • Widest part of pelvis
  2. Plane of Least dimension
    • At the level of S3/4
    • At the level of ischial spine
    • Very important plane CLINICALLY
      1. Narrowest part of pelvis
      2. Internal rotation takes place here
      3. Origin of levator ani
      4. Landmark for pudendal block
      5. When engagement occurs, the head is felt at 0 station, i.e., at this plane
      6. Deep Transverse Arrest occurs here

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstetric outlet:

 

  • Refers to the lower part of the pelvic outlet, which is wider than the anatomical outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option B. Anatomical outlet:

 

  • Refers to the narrowest part of the pelvic outlet.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Option C. Pelvic inlet:

 

  • Marks the entrance to the true pelvis.
  • Not shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The plane of the mid-pelvis (or mid cavity) is a crucial area within the true pelvis, significant for various clinical considerations during labor and delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

questions.text: What is the neoadjuvant therapy used for GIST? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Imatinib

 

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are most commonly associated with mutations in the KIT gene or PDGFRA gene. Imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is used as neoadjuvant therapy for GISTs to shrink the tumor before surgery. This is particularly effective in GISTs with KIT mutations and some PDGFRA mutations.

 

However, not all GISTs respond to imatinib. For instance, GISTs with the PDGFRA D842V mutation or those classified as "wild-type" (lacking KIT or PDGFRA mutations) do not respond well to imatinib. In such cases, surgery is considered the primary treatment option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prednisolone: Prednisolone is a corticosteroid used in various inflammatory and autoimmune conditions but not typically used for GISTs.

 

Option C. Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent used in certain cancers and autoimmune conditions, but it is not used for GISTs.

 

Option D. Indomethacin:  Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain and inflammation but has no role in the treatment of GISTs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imatinib is the preferred neoadjuvant therapy for GISTs with KIT or certain PDGFRA mutations to reduce tumor size before surgery. It is not effective for all GISTs, particularly those with specific mutations such as PDGFRA D842V or "wild-type" GISTs.

questions.text: Multiple Lisch nodules are a feature of which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurofibromatosis

 

Lisch nodules are melanocytic hamartomas found on the iris and are a hallmark of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). They are usually benign and do not affect vision. However, their presence is a key diagnostic criterion for NF1. Neurofibromatosis is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple noncancerous (benign) tumors of nerves and skin (neurofibromas), cafe-au-lait macules (light brown skin spots), and skin fold freckling. Another significant feature is plexiform neurofibroma, which can present congenitally.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: This is incorrect. Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by different skin lesions such as hypomelanotic macules (ash leaf spots), facial angiofibromas, and Shagreen patches. Lisch nodules are not associated with this condition.

 

Option C. Leprosy: This is incorrect. Leprosy (Hansen's disease) primarily affects the skin, nerves, and mucous membranes, but it does not involve the development of Lisch nodules.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: This is incorrect. Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas, often affecting the lungs and lymph nodes, but not associated with Lisch nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lisch nodules are pigmented iris hamartomas specific to Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and are an important diagnostic feature of this condition.

questions.text: A boy who is accused of rape has been brought for medicolegal examination. He was claiming to be 16 years but was suspected to be 18 years. Which X-ray will be done to confirm? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wrist and Knee Joint

 

The purpose of the X-ray in this context is to determine the boy’s age, specifically whether he is above or below 18 years, which is a crucial age threshold in legal context. The fusion of growth plates in certain joints can help estimate age. The wrist and knee joints are reliable indicators for this purpose because they typically fuse between 17 to 19 years of age. This range helps to conclusively determine if the individual is likely above or below 18 years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow and Ankle Joint: These joints typically fuse by 16 to 17 years of age. Therefore, they can only confirm if someone is above 16 but cannot conclusively determine if they are 18 or older.

 

Option C. Head and Shoulder Joint: The shoulder joint may fuse around the age of 17 to 19, but the skull sutures (head) fuse much later, often after 30 years, making this combination ineffective for age determination at 18 years.

 

Option D. Elbow and Hip Joint: The elbow joint does not provide conclusive evidence for determining age at 18 as it fuses earlier (around 16 to 17 years). The hip joint can be useful but is not as definitive as the wrist and knee for this age range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-rays of the wrist and knee joints are the most reliable for determining whether an individual is around the age of 18 due to the typical fusion age range of these joints (17 to 19 years).

questions.text: A child presents with erythematous scaly patches in the perioral region, mucosal ulcers, and impaired epithelial wound healing. What is the likely mineral deficiency associated with this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc deficiency

 

The clinical features of periorificial dermatitis and stomatitis in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, seen in zinc deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency - Most common micronutrient deficiency globally. It presents with iron-deficiency anemia. It presents clinically with pallor, fatigue, weakness, shortness of breath, light-headedness.

 

Option C. Calcium deficiency - Leads to rickets in children. Apart from clinical vignette of rickets there can be Muscle cramps and stiffness, Tingling and Numbness, Tetany.

 

Option D. Copper deficiency - Leads to anemia, growth retardation, defective keratinization and pigmentation of hair, hypothermia, degenerative changes in aortic elastin, osteopenia, and neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency disorder- Acrodermatitis enteropathica

questions.text: What is the key mechanism leading to tissue damage in patients with prolonged diabetes? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperglycemia

 

The primary mechanism leading to tissue damage in diabetes is persistent hyperglycemia, which:

 

  • Leads to oxidative stress
  • Promotes formation of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs)
  • Causes endothelial dysfunction and inflammation

 

Most microvascular complications (neuropathy, nephropathy, retinopathy) are directly attributed to chronic hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sorbitol accumulation: Plays a secondary role, particularly in diabetic neuropathy and cataracts, but is not the primary cause of damage

 

Option C. Insulin resistance: Contributes to hyperglycemia, but does not directly cause tissue damage

 

Option D. Decreased insulin secretion: Leads to hyperglycemia, but tissue damage occurs due to persistent high glucose levels

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperglycemia is the fundamental mechanism causing tissue damage in prolonged diabetes, leading to various microvascular complications.

choices.text: ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.text: Diphtheria toxin MOA is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

 

Diphtheria toxin exerts its toxic effects by inhibiting protein synthesis in the host cell. The mechanism involves the ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2), which is a critical component in the protein synthesis machinery of the cell. By modifying EF-2, diphtheria toxin prevents the translocation step in protein elongation, effectively halting protein production. This leads to cell death and contributes to the pathogenic effects of the infection.

 

Mnemonic "Delhi Public Secondary School" (DPSS): The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acting on 60s Ribosome: This is incorrect because diphtheria toxin specifically targets elongation factor 2 (EF-2) rather than the ribosome directly. It interferes with protein synthesis by modifying EF-2, not by acting on the ribosome.

 

Option B. Increasing cAMP: This option is incorrect as it describes the mechanism of action of other bacterial toxins like those produced by Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). These toxins increase the intracellular levels of cAMP by activating adenyl cyclase, which is not the mechanism for diphtheria toxin.

 

Option C. Decreasing cGMP: This is incorrect. The mechanism involving the decrease of cGMP is not relevant to diphtheria toxin. Diphtheria toxin's action is specific to inhibiting protein synthesis through the ADP ribosylation of EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MOA

 

The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis by modifying EF-2: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin. (Mnemonic: Delhi Public Secondary School /DPSS)

 

The four toxin act by increasing cAMP: Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). (Mnemonic: Be Very Efficient Boy/BVEB)

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy

questions.text: Identify the use of the instrument given below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) For tubal ligation

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument shown is a laparoscopic ring applicator, also known as a laparocator. It is specifically designed for tubal ligation procedures. The instrument is used to apply Falope rings (silastic bands) on the fallopian tubes, which effectively block the tubes and prevent pregnancy. The Falope rings are preloaded on the tip of the instrument and are released after grasping the fallopian tube, thereby occluding the lumen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument shown is not used for ligating the uterine artery. Instead, instruments like clamps or ligature carriers are typically used for this purpose during a hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Ovarian cystectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument is not used for ovarian cystectomy, which involves the removal of cysts from the ovary. Instruments like scissors, graspers, and cautery devices are commonly used in ovarian cystectomy procedures.

 

Option D. Ectopic pregnancy: This is incorrect. While laparoscopic instruments are used in the surgical management of ectopic pregnancy, the specific instrument shown (laparoscopic ring applicator) is not used for this purpose. Instruments used for ectopic pregnancy surgery include laparoscopic graspers, scissors, and suction devices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The laparoscopic ring applicator (laparocator) is used for applying Falope rings during tubal ligation procedures.

 

Ref: Page no 497, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the image shown below. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pressure epiphysis
