  • A pressure epiphysis is the portion of the long bone that shapes the joint. 
  • Pressure epiphyses are the regions of the bone that are under pressure during movement or locomotion and aid in transmitting the weight of the human body. 
  • The head of the humerus, femoral and tibial condyles, ankle joint are the examples. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atavistic epiphysis: A phylogenetically independent bone that has been fused with another bone. The coracoid process of the scapula, which has been fused in humans but is distinct in four-legged animals, is an example of atavistic fused bones. Another example of atavistic epiphysis is the os trigonum (posterior tubercle of the talus).

 

Option C. Traction epiphysis: The non-articular regions of the long bone, which are not involved in joint formation. These areas do not aid in weight transmission. The supporting ligaments and tendons bind to these areas of the bone due to their proximity to the pressure epiphysis site. Pressure epiphyses ossify first, followed by traction epiphyses. Tubercles of the humerus and trochanters of the femur are examples of traction epiphyses.

 

Option D. Aberrant epiphysis: These epiphyses are not necessarily present and are deviated from the standard. The epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal bone, as well as the epiphysis at the base of other metacarpal bones, are examples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the ankle joint. 
  • The joints are formed by the pressure epiphysis regions which are weight bearing areas. 
  • Thus, the ankle joint is an example of pressure epiphysis.

choices.text: Add a second oral hypoglycemic agent

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is on metformin therapy (500 mg BD). Their recent HbA1c is 7.6%, and their last blood glucose reading was 169 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increase the dose of metformin

 

Explanation:

 

The patient’s HbA1c of 7.6% is above the target of <7%, indicating suboptimal glycemic control.

 

  • Metformin is the first-line therapy for type 2 diabetes
  • The current dose (500 mg BD) is below the maximum effective dose
  • Metformin can be increased up to 2000 mg/day (1000 mg BD) before adding another agent

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discontinue metformin: Incorrect, as it is the first-line treatment for diabetes

 

Option C. Add a second agent: Not necessary until maximizing metformin dose

 

Option D. Initiate insulin therapy: Reserved for severely uncontrolled diabetes (HbA1c >9% or symptomatic hyperglycemia)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optimization of metformin dosage (up to 2000 mg/day) should be attempted before adding additional diabetes medications when glycemic control is suboptimal.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and weakness. On evaluation, CBC reveals low hemoglobin with increased reticulocyte count. Comment on the likely diagnosis. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemolytic anemia

 

The clinical presentation of fatigue, pallor, and weakness, along with the laboratory findings of low hemoglobin and increased reticulocyte count, strongly suggests hemolytic anemia.

 

In hemolytic anemia, there is an increased destruction of red blood cells (RBCs), which leads to a compensatory increase in the production of RBCs by the bone marrow. This increased production is reflected by a higher reticulocyte count, which indicates that the bone marrow is responding to the anemia by releasing more immature red blood cells (reticulocytes) into the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: Typically presents with pancytopenia (low counts of all blood cells) and a low reticulocyte count, reflecting bone marrow failure.

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: Often shows a normal or low reticulocyte count because the bone marrow is not responding effectively due to chronic inflammation or disease.

 

Option C. Folate deficiency: Leads to megaloblastic anemia, where there is impaired DNA synthesis, resulting in large, immature RBCs with a normal or low reticulocyte count.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increased reticulocyte count in the presence of low hemoglobin suggests an overactive bone marrow, often due to hemolytic anemia, where the body compensates for increased RBC destruction by ramping up RBC production.

choices.text: B12 (Vitamin B12)

questions.text: The micronutrient that is deficient after ileal resection:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B12 (Vitamin B12)

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: Ileal resection can lead to malabsorption of vitamin B12, as the ileum is the primary site for the absorption of this vitamin in the small intestine.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Folate: While the absorption of folate can be affected by certain intestinal conditions, ileal resection primarily impacts the absorption of vitamin B12, not folate.

 

Option C. Iron: Ileal resection can lead to malabsorption of various nutrients, but vitamin B12 deficiency is more specifically associated with ileal resection.

 

Option D. Copper: Copper is absorbed in the stomach and proximal small intestine, and deficiencies are not commonly associated with ileal resection.

 

Educational objective:

 

The intrinsic factor, produced in the stomach, binds to vitamin B12 in the ileum, allowing for its absorption. Ileal resection can result in a deficiency of vitamin B12, leading to pernicious anemia and neurological symptoms.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 544
